In this study we will assess the benefits of these tools for patients and GPs in reaching a diagnosis, commencing evidence-based management and achieving relief of breathlessness.

name: Understanding the perspectives of Indigenous entrepreneurs
description: This project explores Indigenous entrepreneurs’ perceptions and attitudes to tax requirements to understand how all stakeholders involved in the tax system can better assist Indigenous communities to achieve their entrepreneurial goals as well as helping them grow.

name: Evaluating diversity in Health Professions Students
description: The research will involve a qualitative study to investigate the diversity of health professions students and the impacts on their learning and support needs

name: Towards successful integration: challenges and opportunities for acculturation of Black Sub-Saharan Africans who are living in Australia.
description: The aim of this project is to assess intergenerational conflict between Black Australian Africa born parents and their children and identify tools for promoting successful integration. The hypothesis is that there will be significant family distance between Africa born parents and their children.

name: Co-Designing a Psychotherapy Program for Premenstrual Change
description: This study aims to design, implement, and evaluate a psychotherapy program for individuals experiencing negative premenstrual change (PMC). It consists of three stages. First, an online survey and one-to-one interviews explored experiences of PMC and priorities for psychotherapy. Next, a tailored psychotherapy program will be developed and delivered, informed by the survey and interview data. The program will incorporate mixed-method data collection, including therapy session recordings and arts-based research methods. Finally, follow-up interviews will examine participants’ experiences and constructions of the psychotherapy program. This research addresses a gap in women’s health and mental health, with the potential to enhance psychotherapeutic support for PMC.

name: Enabling leaders and members within consecrated life communities
description: Consecrated life is a divine gift from God to the Church through the Holy Spirit, rooted deeply in the example and teachings of Christ (Pope Paul, 1996). Consecrated life communities, as described by Kanu (2019) and Noronha (2019), are unique societal structures where individuals, guided by the Holy Spirit, commit to poverty, chastity, and obedience, dedicating themselves to God and symbolising the life to come. This research aims to enhance understanding of leader-member relationships within these communities, thereby contributing to their overall well-being, and sustainability. The study aims to illuminate specific leadership approaches, leadership development, and subjective well-being and community environment within these unique settings. To achieve this, the study will employ a small-scale autoethnography, drawing on my personal experiences as a community member. Additionally, a combination of qualitative research methods, including semi-structured interviews and focus groups, will be applied to captivate diverse perspectives from leaders and members. The anticipated outcomes of this research include a comprehensive understanding of leader-member dynamics within consecrated life communities and practical insights to bridge generational and relational gaps. The findings could potentially inform leadership practices and contribute to the well-being of these communities, thereby having a significant societal impact.

name: Towards the validity of the Reflectal Psychosocial Hazard Measure: A pilot study
description: The main aim of this pilot project is to investigate the validity and reliability of the Reflectal Psychosocial Hazard Measure. Furthermore, the correlations between the sub-scales (e.g., role clarity, job demands, bullying) that make up psychosocial hazards in the workplace, as measured by the proposed scale, will be explored to help assess convergent and divergent validity. This research will inform further development and the validation of longitudinal data collection at a later phase (phase two).

name: A pilot study into assessing the danger of heated-tobacco-products
description: The project aims to assess histological changes in 3D human airway models exposed to aerosols from heated-tobacco-products to determine negative health implications associated with their consumption.

name: Responsiveness of patient-reported outcome measures in adults with chronic low back pain: a retrospective clinimetric analysis.
description: This research project aims to investigate the responsiveness of various pain measures in chronic low back pain (CLBP) patients, using data from the RESOLVE randomized controlled trial (RCT). Traditionally, pain intensity scores like VAS or VNRS are used to measure CLBP, but other patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) such as global perceived effect (GPE), bothersomeness, and disability scales might offer a more comprehensive view of the patient's experience. The study will retrospectively analyze data from 138 participants who received sensorimotor treatment intervention, assessing the internal responsiveness (IR) and external responsiveness (ER) of different pain measures.

name: Midwives Experiences of Water Immersion for Vaginal Birth After Caesarean
description: This research aims to explore midwives’ experiences of providing water immersion care for women trialing a vaginal birth after caesarean (VBAC).  This research will follow a qualitative approach guided by phenomenology as the methodology underpinned by a constructivist theoretical framework. Participants will consist of registered midwives in Western Australia who have experienced providing water immersion care for a woman undergoing a VBAC. Data will be collected primary through a qualitative survey, with an optional one-on-one interview online. The data obtained from midwives’ experiences will provide important perspectives of healthcare practitioners experiences, contributing to the growing body of research surrounding water immersion and VBAC, and assist in improving maternal and neonatal health outcomes.

name: The cycle of relationship sabotage: From communication of romantic interest to dissolution of intimate engagements
description: When searching for love, some people are stuck in a continuous cycle of successfully initiating a relationship, not being able to maintain long-term engagements, and embarking upon a path to a destined break-up. Others are stuck in relationships they are not happy with. And, some have given-up on having relationships altogether. The concept of relationship sabotage can explain why and how this phenomenon occurs; however no empirical research existed in this area until recently. Research needs to continue to further validate the newly developed Relationship Sabotage Scale. Additionally, research in this area will benefit from exploring how individuals’ differences contribute to relationship difficulties in young people and adults.

name: A study of physical, emotional, and verbal aggression towards teachers by students in Western Australia
description: The purpose of this mixed methods study is to explore physical, emotional, and verbal aggression towards teachers by students (PEVATTS) in Western Australia (WA). It aims to provide important foundational research on the frequency, forms, impacts, support, training, and prevention of PEVATTS.

name: Prevalence and Impact of Frailty and Obesity among Heart Lung Clinic Patients: A Retrospective Cohort Study
description: This study will use data from the Heart Lung Clinic database. First, we will conduct a cross-sectional study evaluating the prevalence of frailty with and without obesity at the time of first assessment by the heart-lung clinic. Secondly, we will perform a retrospective cohort study to evaluate the impact of frailty and obesity on transplant-related outcomes. The study will determine whether frailty predicts outcomes independent of obesity or amplifies the effect of obesity on outcomes. Patients will be stratified into obese-frail, obese-non-frail, non-obese-frail, and non-obese-non-frail groups based on frailty assessment at baseline, and outcomes will be compared between these groups.

name: Data use in schools
description: This pilot study aims to explore community perceptions of technology use in schools, particularly the use of personal digital devices (e.g., laptops, tablets) in classroom learning. It serves as an initial step in a broader research program examining how technology-dominant classroom practices — especially 1:1 device models — influence teaching practice, student engagement, and learning outcomes.

name: Forewarned or Forearmed? Comparing the impacts of financial aid and preparedness training on equity groups’ experience of ‘placement poverty’
description: The project aims to examine the impacts of 'placement poverty' of a targeted cohort of Bachelor of Nursing students, with particular interest in the impacts of student from equity cohorts. The projects will evaluate and compare the impact of two interventions – individual financial support and an online education module – on students participation, placement experience, and overall wellbeing during their practicums.

name: Repercussions of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Surgical Patient Population in Western Australia: Associations with Post-Surgery Complications, in the Context of Modifiable Lifestyle Risk Factors
description:
This research is a quantitative study linking audited patient modifiable lifestyle factors with patient surgery outcome data to determine the associated implications of Covid-related surgery suspension during the period of March to April 2020 and the community-imposed restrictions from March 2020 at Fiona Stanley Hospital in Western Australia. The novel study will be a case control examination of the first wave of Covid-19 using a 2019 and 2020 comparison cohort. 	
A retrospective medical chart review was conducted in 2022, using 2,353 patient notes to document lifestyle behaviours such as smoking, alcohol use for harm, malnutrition, physical fitness, high body mass index, and frailty on patient health questionnaires or related pre-surgery notes. Further analysis will be conducted using this cohort to investigate the significance of lifestyle behaviour changes during the Covid-19 phase in early 2020 and significance to post surgery outcomes associated with extended waitlist times to surgery. 
The implications of this research will inform decision making for preparations and planning for future pandemics on the delivery of elective surgery services and patient healthy lifestyle information prior to surgery.

name: Culturally Regenerative Universities
description: Climate change threatens human well-being and planetary health… (IPCC, 2023, p. 24). In response, a team will research ways to create regenerative cultures in universities. How can universities become places of cultural regeneration? Researchers from six universities will investigate strengths within their own workplaces, maximising accomplishments in cultural regeneration, and sharing them. We plan to inspire and support tertiary institutions to address the challenges humanity faces relating to crises in climate, environments, societies, and within the socio-emotional, spiritual, and physical wellbeing of people. A concept paper (Wooltorton, Stephenson, et al., 2025) outlines a vision.

name: Colin Clark: a Contributor to Dialogue between Catholic Social Teaching and Economics
description: The PhD project is an archival-based thesis on the economic ideas of Colin Clark (1905 - 1989) and its relation to Catholic Social Teaching. Archival papers will be collected from the Fryer Library at the University of Queensland, the State Library of Victoria, the Historical Commission of the Catholic Archdiocese of Melbourne, and the University of Melbourne. The project is a historical project of developments in Catholic Social Teaching and social thought with an emphasis in Australia, as well as the UK, and the USA in the 20th century. The main focus is on Clark's application of CST in the economic field. It will also examine his association with BA Santamaria, the Australian Catholic political activist.

name: International Service Learning: A Transformative Tool for Critical Global Citizenship
description: This study will implement a convergent mixed methods methodology, employing a holistic case study design to understand the impacts of International Service Learning (ISL) on the knowledge and enactment of Critical Global Citizenship (CGC).  A pragmatic lens will make use of both qualitative, post placement focus group data and quantitative pre and post placement survey data to analyse immediate ISL transformation. Interpretive phenomenological analysis will gather data from purposefully sampled ISL participants who have enacted CGC in the long term. Emerging themes will serve to illuminate the transformative potential of ISL and the relevant impacting factors that encourage long term commitment to CGC.

name: Transnational Wellness: Yoga in Australia and North America
description: This research project will investigate how yoga manifests and is practiced in Australia. We will compare our findings in Australia with those from Paul Bramadat’s previous research on yoga in North America to see whether there are meaningful differences and/or similarities between yoga in Australia and North America. This includes considering whether the influence of India is different in the two contexts, and the relevance of nation-specific policies on, for example, healthcare and indigenous reconciliation.

name: Implementation and evaluation of the co-created Midwifery Student Peer Debriefing Tool: A Hybrid Type 1 study
description: The aim of this project is to explore the effectiveness and the implementability of the Midwifery Student Peer Debriefing Tool (Buchanan et al., 2024), in the intended implementation settings and to evaluate the implementation process. We intend to use Hybrid Type 1 methodology (described by Landes et al., 2020) for this project. The predominant focus will be on testing the clinical intervention’s effectiveness, but exploration of implementation related factors will also be conducted. We will employ a simple evaluation survey to determine effectiveness, and we will also complete a process evaluation to capture participants’ implementation experience, their suggestions for the intervention’s adaption for use in real world midwifery practice, and/or what else they feel is required to prepare /support the people and place implementing the Tool.

name: The Providing Enhanced ACcess to Health Services (PEACH) Evaluation – A Priority Populations Program of Study
description: Background: Children and young people (0–16 years, 17–24 years) with intellectual disability have long been known to experience inequities in accessing healthcare1,2. They show a significant difference in health outcomes and life expectancy when compared with the general population. Sometimes this is associated with their diagnosis or disability but is more commonly a result of healthcare barriers and systems that do not meet their needs. In addition, for those who receive healthcare, many have negative experiences, including adverse patient safety events such as medication errors, wrong procedures or iatrogenic injury3,4. One of the key barriers cited in literature relates to be difficulties in identification of flagging of these children and young people in need of reasonable adjustments5. In response the Sydney Children’s Hospital’s network (SCHN) has developed an alert and flagging system – All About Me- that staff can use to record information about the child or young person in need of adjustments.  It is meant to inform clinical teams whether they need to make reasonable adjustments to improve the safety, quality and experience of hospital care for vulnerable children and young people.   Aim: To investigate the reach of the All About Me improvement initiative. Research questions: 1) what is the efficacy of the time  in enabling reasonable adjustments and 2) what is the impact on children and adolescents with intellectual and developmental disability ID/IDD experience and outcomes.

name: Early Primary Teachers’ Understanding of Sight Words: A Picture Paints a Thousand Words but a Word is Not a Picture
description: This study aims to gain insight into the dominant pedagogy, knowledge and word-level teaching practises of Australian early primary teachers (classroom, learning support and/or literacy coaches) working with students in their first four years of schooling from Foundation to Year 3 (F-3).  This research has a non-experimental mixed methods design that aims to collect two types of data: quantitative data via an anonymous survey (phase one), followed by semi-structured interviews from a random sample of Australian teachers (classroom, learning support, literacy coaches) working in Foundation (year before year 1) to year 3 classrooms (phase two & three). The research utilises both quantitative and qualitative methods. The methods are mixed as an anonymous online survey (using Qualtrics) was used to gather objective and measurable data. This data will be uploaded to and analysed using SPSS software. Interviews will be recorded on Teams and transcribed and analysed using Nvivo software.

name: A Prospective Cohort Study Evaluating the Impact of Psycho-Existential Concerns on a Desire for Death
description:
Our primary objective is to examine the prevalence of a Desire for Hastened Death (DHD) and its association with psycho-existential distress as measured on the Psycho-existential Symptom Assessment Scale in patients with an advanced illness and an estimated prognosis of ≤12 months 
Secondary
1.	To explore the correlations of the DHD with sociodemographic and disease-related factors, distressing physical symptoms, levels of dependency and quality of life.
2.	To examine the mediators of this development of a desire to hasten death (DHD).

name: Undertaking the P4 Study: The participants’ experience
description: Undertaking the P4 study: The participants’ experience is a substudy of the prospective cohort P4 study. The original P4 study (Postpartum physiology, psychology and paediatric) enrolled participants at St George hospital, who gave birth in the preceding 6-months. The participants were normotensive, had gestational hypertension or pre-eclampsia and were assessed at six-months, two-years and five-years after birth for anthropometric, blood pressure, and psychological assessment. The babies were examined by a paediatrician and their mother, at each time-point, and a psychologist at two-years. The substudy investigates the participants’ experience throughout P4, through a questionnaire administered at the 5-year time-point that includes two open-ended questions and a closed-question allowing participants the opportunity to provide feedback on their clinical trial experience. The data collected will procure an understanding of the impacts of clinical trials on participants, aiding researchers in creating studies that are acceptable and welcomed by the general population.

name: Developing Skills for Intimate Relationships: A Qualitative Analysis of Reddit posts
description: This study aims to explore how those with lived experiences of relationship difficulties seek relationship and dating advice on social media. Little research has focused on how informal advice (obtained from social media, especially) impacts on people’s relationships. Understanding real life relationship advice seeking and advice giving is critical as many individuals struggle with dating and relationship difficulties and is a prominent reason why individuals seek counselling

name: Barriers and Enablers of Nurse-led Skin Cancer Screening in Rural Australia
description: Australia has among the highest incidence of skin cancer in the world; two out of three people in Australia will have some form of skin cancer by age 70. Those living in regional and rural areas have a higher incidence of skin cancer than their metropolitan counterparts, and yet, the reach of skin cancer services to regional, rural, and remote Australia is limited to non-existent. General Practitioners (GPs) are primarily responsible for opportunistic skin cancer detection, often made difficult by constrains on consult times, further exacerbated by the maldistribution of primary care providers in rural areas. One solution may be to better utilise nurses as primary providers of skin checks in collaboration with these GPs. This study will examine the barriers and enablers of nurse-led skin checks in rural Australia. Semi-structured interviews will be used to assess the perceived barriers and enablers to a nurse-led screening model, from the perspective of the practitioners who deliver these services. If successful, this project will highlight how to improve future implementation of a nurse-led screening model, and better position future skin screening methods for uptake in rural communities.

name: Investigating the Impact of World Youth Day (WYD) on pilgrims form Parramatta Catholic Schools
description: One of the major consequences of changing demographic and social patterns is that the mission and identity of Catholic schools is an area that needs ongoing support and cultivation.  One way Catholic schools are doing this is supporting events with have a direct focus on evangelization and mission.  There has been considerable effort made to support teacher and student participation in WYD.  This has been a longstanding commitment.   Catholic Schools Parramatta Diocese (CSPD) is one system that has sponsored teachers and student pilgrims and is seeking to evaluate the impact of this participation on pilgrims.

name: A novel antisense oligonucleotide therapeutic to restore defective splicing in ALS
description: The purpose of this project is to take a precision medicine approach and design a drug that is specifically targeted to correct mutations that are present in the ALS gene KIF5A. Drug sequences will be screened in stem cells from an ALS patient harbouring a KIF5A mutation that results in the skipping of exon 27 (part of the protein coding sequence). The goal of this project is to restore the expression of full length KIF5A protein in patient cells.

name: Foot muscle measures of strength and cross-sectional area by ultrasound in the Diabetic Population
description: Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy (DPN) is a prevalent and debilitating condition. One way of detecting and managing DPN is to assess the Intrinsic Foot Muscles (IFM). Ultrasound (US) has been used as a measure to detect IFM muscular atrophy in DPN patients. In addition, exercise is beneficial in delaying the usual course of DPN, skin damage and ulceration. However, diabetic patients have lower physical activity rates due to limitations such as difficult access to therapy, poor compliance, and limited support to maintain exercise therapy. Therefore, this study aims to assess whether a newly developed biofeedback device, 'Archercise' – a foot muscle exercise and strengthening tool, can correlate IFM Cross-Sectional Area (CSA) measured by US with foot arch control and performance.

name: Pleurodesis versus Indwelling pleural catheters in the context of relief of dyspnoea in malignant pleural effusion
description: Retrospective study comparing the use of pleurodesis and in-dwelling pleural catheter for the management of malignant pleural effusions at St Vincent’s Hospital.

name: Under the weather: Climate Vulnerability and Homelessness
description:
Climate change is a modern concern for the health of individuals who are unable to avoid the growing number of extreme weather events – such as people experiencing homelessness. 

The overall aim of this project is to examine the effects of climate on the health and wellbeing of people experiencing homelessness, the climate and weather events people experiencing homelessness are exposed to, and the impact of supports, interventions and services that aim to mitigate the impacts of climate change and associated severe weather events.

name: Hybrid Catheter Ablation and Surgical Ablation as a ‘Bail Out’ Strategy In Patients with Atrial Fibrillation Resistant To Catheter Ablation
description:
Description textAtrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common arrythmia increasing the risk of stroke and limiting one’s ability to carry out day to day activities. Catheter ablation uses various forms of energy to ablate aberrant parts of the left atrium, thus restoring a normal rhythm. While this treatment is effective for patients with short-lasting AF, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (PAF), the outcomes for patients with longer standing AF, persistent AF (PsAF) and long-standing persistent AF (LSPAF), are suboptimal. The Hybrid Catheter Ablation and Surgical Ablation (HyCASA) procedure was developed to treat patients with difficult-to-treat AF. It combines catheter ablation of the endocardium, performed by a cardiologist, with surgical ablation of the epicardium, performed by a cardiothoracic surgeon, in either a staged or concurrent approach. This procedure has the advantage of creating a durable lesion of the posterior left atrium while minimizing the risk of damage to local structures, such as the oesophagus. This procedure has been shown to be more effective than catheter ablation alone for PsAF and LsPAF, with acceptable safety.  
Our primary aim is to investigate the efficacy of the HyCASA procedure in patients with AF who have previously failed at least one catheter ablation and anti-arrythmic drugs. Procedural efficacy will be demonstrated by the proportion of patients who fail the procedure over at least 12 months of follow up time. We will also demonstrate efficacy using AF burden over 12 months, where AF burden is the time spent in AF divided by the total monitoring time. 
This is important research to conduct because it provides evidence as to whether the HyCASA procedure is a viable option for patients with AF who failed catheter ablation and anti-arrythmic drugs previously.

name: Tjuntjuntjara remote Aboriginal service-learning immersion: Look back, looking forward
description: This project aims to explore the perceptions of former preservice teachers with respect to undertaking an eight-day service-learning immersion in a remote Aboriginal community in Western Australia.  The focus is on the professional and personal impact such an immersion had participants' initial teacher education.

name: A case study at Rozelle Total Health Clinic: A qualitative review of the patient and GP experience using AI (Lyrebird) for recording consultations.
description: The aim of this project is to explore the impact of AI technology on healthcare consultations from the GP and patient perspective and its alignment with the quintuple aims of healthcare.  This project involves GP's and patients at the Rozelle Clinic completing a survey and an interview with the researchers. Data from the surveys and interviews will be analysed to explore the impact of AI as described in the aim above.

name: Enhancing clinical outcomes in patients with heart failure using data linkage of Medicare funded pathology services for iron deficiency.
description: Iron deficiency is common in heart failure patients, and effective treatment improves symptoms and quality of life. Australian guidelines recommend iron testing and treatment, but the real-world implementation and impact are unclear. Utilising MBS and other data in the National Health Data Hub, linked to the National Echo Database of Australia, this required information can be obtained, delivering efficient, evidence-based healthcare measures while ensuring privacy. The data will benchmark iron testing against guidelines, evaluate the impact of timely intravenous iron therapy, assess outcomes like hospitalisations and mortality, and guide clinical decisions on choosing the correct MBS iron item and retesting frequency. It will empower patients to discuss results with clinicians and improve clinical support tools across disciplines. The initiative aims to drive practice change, enhance patient awareness, support ongoing research, and set a precedent for using linked MBS/PBS data.

name: PharmaVape: investigating sales of vapes through pharmacies in Australia
description: The aim of this project is to examine the availability of vapes through pharmacies across Australia before and after the federally legislated change in e-cigarette scheduling on 1 October 2024 from prescription to pharmacy-only medicine.  The research project is a collaboration primarily between the research team based within the IHR at UNDA and tobacco control colleagues from Cancer Council Victoria. However, tobacco control colleagues at organisations in other states/territories will also be partners through committing staff or student time to undertake fieldwork for the study.

name: Prevalence of medical comorbidities in paediatric cochlear implant recipients at Perth Children’s Hospital
description: This project aims to use data collected from paediatric cochlear implant recipients from Perth Children’s Hospital (PCH), to analyse the prevalence and types of medical comorbidities within this population. Studies have shown that a significant proportion of patients with congenital deafness also have additional medical comorbidities, many of which are associated with poorer surgical and developmental outcomes. Importantly, patients with medical comorbidities are frequently excluded from cochlear implant studies, so published research investigating outcomes may not accurately reflect a large proportion of the patient population. PCH is the main tertiary implant clinic for paediatric patients in the state, and having more information about the prevalence of comorbidities within the implant patient population may influence future outcomes for these patients. This project would allow implant teams to contextualise the outcomes for patients more broadly by comparing those with and without medical comorbidities. The findings will be important for future service provision and planning and allow comparison of outcomes with the literature and other implant centres with a similar comorbid composition.

name: Stroke Incidence and management in Far West NSW and the benefits of mobile stroke units
description: Description textRetrospective analysis of deidentified flight and clinical data from RFDS South Eastern Sector. Examining the healthcare sites in this region and accessibility of medical imaging services. Extrapolation of average retrieval time from sites without imaging to sites with imaging to determine the potential delays in stroke diagnosis and treatment within the region.

name: Assessing Gait with Digital Video in Patients with Suspected Neuromuscular Conditions
description: This project aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of a smartphone-based digital video tool to assess gait in patients with suspected neuromuscular conditions. By comparing gait parameters extracted from video recordings with clinical diagnoses made by neurosurgeons, the study investigates whether simple video analysis can reliably detect conditions like degenerative cervical myelopathy. The goal is to provide a low-cost, accessible diagnostic method that could improve early detection and monitoring, especially in resource-limited or remote settings.

name: Binational survey to map services for adolescents and young adults with solid organ transplants in Australia and NZ
description: The role of transplant centres and healthcare workers in providing dedicated services to support the ongoing care of AYA recipients is therefore crucial in transition phases (Ullrich et al., 2004). Transplant centres provide follow-up care and monitoring and offer a range of support services, including counselling, education, and resources to help patients and their families navigate the transplant process and adjust to life post-transplant. However, there is minimal literature of transplant centre impact on the transition period for AYA solid-organ recipients and there is a lack of uniformity of programs and resources for pre- and post-transplant care of AYA’s in Australia and New Zealand.  To gain a better understanding of existing services, practices, protocols and support structures in transplant centres in Australia and New Zealand, we propose an exploratory survey of healthcare providers who provide transplantation services for solid organ transplant recipients in Australia and New Zealand. It is hoped that these results will identify areas of strength and gaps in services that can be targeted to improve the services and outcomes for AYA solid organ transplant recipients.

name: Evaluating the WA Health Paid Employment Model for midwifery students
description: Globally, health services are experiencing shortages of midwifery professionals. Similar to other international and national jurisdictions, Western Australia (WA) is grappling with shortages in the midwifery workforce exacerbated by the COVID pandemic, strict border closures and midwives leaving profession. To promote the growth and sustainability of the midwifery workforce, the Chief Nursing and Midwifery Office has partnered with The University of Notre Dame to establish a pilot ‘Paid Employment Model’ for midwifery students. This model supports Registered Nurses to undertake a Diploma of Midwifery while retaining paid part-time employment within a WA HSP. It is envisaged that this model will attract and retain midwifery students who are then employed as professional midwives after graduation. WA Health has funded 60 students, 40 in WACHS and 20 in metropolitan settings, to undertake the pilot program along with six clinical facilitators to provide on-site support. This project aims to evaluate the implementation, effectiveness, impact and economic benefit of the Paid Employment Model for midwifery students.

name: Survival analysis of early-stage NSCLC patients following lobectomy: impact of surgical techniques and other variables on long-term outcomes
description: This study aims to assess the long-term survival outcomes of patients who underwent VATS lobectomy for NSCLC in comparison to those who had an open procedure. This research will provide valuable insights into the impact of the VATS procedure on long-term survival rates. The findings of this paper will expand upon the existing body of knowledge by offering evidence on the long-term benefits.

name: Reliability of AI scoring for personalised melanoma immunotherapy
description:
Despite advances in cancer treatments and increased survival of advanced melanoma patients, most patients with advanced melanoma will still die when treated with routine immunotherapies due to immune evasive mechanisms[1]. The personalised immunotherapy program will, instead, ensure each patient’s cancer is screened for genetic and immune profiles to identify patients unlikely to benefit from standard therapies. These patients will then be assigned a novel clinical trial agent most likely to cure them based on the presence of the drug targets in the patient's tumour. It is anticipated that selecting treatments for patients, based on the presence of specific drug targets in the patient’s cancer, will improve cancer outcomes and increase the survival of people with cancer. 

This project aims to optimise the multiplex immunohistochemistry staining panel that can be used to rapidly identify the profile of immune checkpoint targets in melanoma biopsies. Further, the project aims to elucidate the accuracy of the artificial intelligence (AI) program to correctly identity fluorescent threshold for immune marker positivity. 

This project will accurately and cost effectively fast track patient assessment for immunotherapy treatments; thereby rapidly matching patients with effective therapies to increase the overall cure rate of advanced cancers.

name: Assessing the health, economic and wellbeing benefits of Homeless Healthcare services in hospital, primary care and community settings
description: The aim of this project is to evaluate the impact of primary, secondary, and tertiary health care services on health outcomes and health service access of people experiencing homelessness in Western Australia (WA). The project commenced in 2016 with small seed funding to evaluate the impact of a range of homelessness interventions on the health outcomes of people experiencing homelessness (PEH) across Perth. Since then, it has expanded (with ethics amendments and site governance approvals as appropriate) to become a longitudinal cohort study of a large group of currently or previously homeless people in WA, most of whom are or have been patients or supported by Homeless Healthcare (HHC) and/or the Royal Perth Hospital (RPH) Homeless Team (RPH Homeless Team)

name: Aboriginal Youth Safe Space Leadership
description: The aim of the research is to contribute towards cultural socio-emotional wellbeing through young people learning to lead collaboratively. This research-integrated project is for young Aboriginal people to learn how to develop and lead a Coolgardie Aboriginal Youth Safe Space, emphasising leadership, Aboriginal culture, values of inclusion and responsibility.

name: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy compared to upfront surgery for borderline-resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma: Exploring the real-world experience in Western Australia
description: This project aims to determine optimal treatment sequencing for borderline resectable pancreatic cancer in regard to both overall and disease-free survival. We aim to determine for which patient groups this survival benefit is most pronounced.

name: Doctors’ health and wellbeing research priorities in Australia and New Zealand: Consensus from a Delphi study.
description:
There is no current evidence-based information to guide what the research priority areas are for Doctors’ health and wellbeing in Australia and New Zealand. 

A group of subject experts will participate in a Delphi study with three online surveys.
Research questions: 
What are the priorities for doctors’ health research in Australia?
What are the priorities for doctors’ health research in New Zealand?

The aims of this study are to:
•	establish consensus regarding the research priorities for doctors’ health and wellbeing in Australia and New Zealand. 
•	define a coordinated national research strategy that enables funding to be allocated where it will be most effective to enable a strong foundation for supporting doctors’ health and wellbeing.

name: Evaluation to fuel advocacy for writer visits in Australian schools
description:
This project will explore how Australian schools evaluate and communicate the impact of writer visits. Based
on findings and Margaret’s expertise in evaluation
and literacy engagement, an open source tool will be developed to support schools’ effectiveness at capturing and promoting the impact of Australian writers on students’ reading engagement.

name: Clinical and Patient-Reported Outcome Measures for Custom Implants used in Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty
Self-enhancement, "Biohacking" and Spiritual Yearning
description: A qualitative investigation into the presence and nature of spiritual yearning among people engaging substantially in biohacking practices and unaffiliated with traditional religion. We will be interviewing 40 participants as part of this study.

name: Understanding the morbidity associated with treating Acute Myeloid Leukaemia (AML) in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children
description:
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children are less likely to be diagnosed with childhood cancers, but are also less likely to survive. By understanding how they tolerate treatment, their side effects experienced and long-term outcomes, we can modify future treatments and better manage their side effects for better survival/quality of life. Conduct a retrospective cohort study on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children with Acute Myeloid Leukaemia, diagnosed at PMH/PCH between 2000 and 2020. Factors including sex, age, location of residence, survival, short- and long-term side effects will be examined. 

Project is a small proportion of a larger project with all childhood cancers being reviewed from the same timeframe mentioned above. Focusing on AML is for practicality for the capstone project as well as offering the larger project a focus on specifical treatments/side effects in AML experienced by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children.

name: Return to performance after a calf muscle strain injury in elite male Australian Football League players: A case-series
description: This project will evaluate time to return to performance in elite Australian football players following calf muscle injury.

name: Social suffering and midwife mothers
description: This study seeks to explore the lived experience of Australian midwives who are mothers (MidMums) and to consider whether elements of social suffering contribute to their choice to remain or to leave the profession. Utilising a critical phenomenological approach, the lived experience of MidMums will be explored during interviews and then critically analysed with respect to the theoretical concept that is social suffering. Study findings have the potential to inform policies and procedures to improve midwives’ professional productivity and emotional wellbeing, and to have a broader impact upon society by contributing to improvements in conditions influencing female workforce, parental support, and gender pay equality.

name: An Increase of Prazosin Association with Deliberate Self Harm Australia: a Retrospective Case Series
description: To conduct a retrospective observational study to assess the relationship between increased prescribing for off-label use of prazosin in mental health disorders (i.e. Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder [PTSD]) and medication related harm (i.e. medication therapeutic error, deliberate self-poisoning [DSP]). The population will include any person in Australia who have had the Poisons Information Centre NSW involved in their clinical management. The intervention group will be those who have been prescribed prazosin with an outcome of deliberately self-poisoning (DSP) and the changes in rates of this over time which will be held in comparison to overall rates of DSP cases in the Poisons Information Centre Database

name: The UNFOLD study - Investigating immunotherapy for chronic lung disease
description: The highly variable clinical outcomes have made it difficult to identify the precise mechanisms involved in the pathogenesis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and thus the development of a specific cure or treatment to halt and reverse the inexorable decline in patient health. Chronic inflammation is a cardinal feature of IPF and is driven by both innate and adaptive immune responses. We recently demonstrated a potential role for antibody secreting plasma B cells (PCs) in the development of bleomycin-induced lung fibrosis in mice. Human studies also showed both elevated serum autoantibodies and elevated numbers of antibody secreting cells in IPF blood, and the accumulation of mature PCs adjacent to areas of active lung fibrosis in IPF lung tissue, supporting a functional role for PCs in IPF pathogenesis. We have used a multi-omics approach to examine the B cell repertoire of a subset of IPF patients and age-matched controls as well as screening IPF patient sera against a proteomic array to identify potential human autoantigens. We have shown that the B cell repertoire in IPF differs to that of control patients, with IPF patients displaying a restricted antibody repertoire compared to controls and evidence of B cell clonal expansion. We have identified a range of novel autoantigens in a subset of IPF patients. These findings suggest an approach for stratifying IPF patients based on an autoimmune phenotype that may inform treatment options for some of these patients. The UNFOLD study investigates the potential of immunotherapy for this chronic lung disease and specifically will 1) Validate specific common autoantigens using larger, geographically disparate IPF patient cohorts. 2) develop more appropriate and sensitive screening assays for early diagnosis and stratification to identify autoimmune IPF patients and 3). Test the suitability of novel plasma cell-specific B cell ablation and CAR-T cell therapy approaches in pre-clinical models of lung fibrosis.

name: Evaluating the implementation of the Spiritual Capabilities Framework for early years educators
description: This project seeks to explore the pedagogical implementation of the Spiritual Capabilities Framework (SCF) as experienced by early years educators. Since 2022, the researchers have worked with MercyCare to provide professional learning to educators on spirituality for young children. A SCF was developed that built on the researchers’ prior work along with the work undertaken with MercyCare. The SCF aims to provide a resource for professionals working with young children seeking to intentionally promote young children’s spirituality as part of their holistic development. This is the first Framework of its kind and as such, understanding the way educators make use of the Framework, and how they come to understand and promote children’s spirituality from its adoption, will be innovative, providing new knowledge in this field. The findings will be impactful for MercyCare specifically, but for the early years sector more broadly as they seek to invest in programs and approaches that assist educators in delivering quality early learning experiences.

name: Comparison of EchoSolv-AS with Human Diagnosis of Severe Aortic Stenosis from Echocardiographic Measurement Data
description:
Aortic Stenosis (AS) is a serious heart condition characterized by the narrowing of the aortic valve and is the cause of substantial morbidity and mortality in Australia. When both moderate and severe, AS is associated with an increased risk of death. The aim of this study is to examine the performance of AI in identifying severe AS compared with specialist Cardiologists, and whether the assistance of the AI (as the “gold standard”) has the potential to improve the quality and consistency of AS reporting.
The objective is to evaluate whether the EchoSolv-AS AI can improve the quality and consistency of AS reporting by correctly identifying guideline-severe AS and the severe AS phenotype.

name: Women's experiences of maternity care in Western Sydney Local Health District (WSLHD) a culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) perspective
description:
In Australia more than 97% of women give birth in hospital. Western Sydney Local Health District (WSLHD) accounts for the highest proportion of births in NSW, and the highest proportion of women from culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) backgrounds.[1] Women who are marginalized, including refugees, migrants, asylum seekers (collectively referred to as CALD), face a multitude of barriers to maternity services, [2] substantially impacting their care. The aim of the study is to understand what constitutes as barriers and facilitators in providing the optimum care for these women, and how we can use this information to facilitate respectful models of care
for them. We will be employing a qualitative study method ( with an interpreter), in-depth face to face individual interviews, utilizing theory - informed interpretive frameworks to understand the CALD's women's experiences.

name: Towards an Understanding of Research Capacity of Allied Health and Nursing and Midwifery Clinicians in the Kimberley Region of Western Australia
description: The aim of this project is to understand the research capacity of Allied Health (AH), and Nursing and Midwifery (NM) clinicians practicing in the Kimberley region of Western Australia.

name: West Kimberley Climate Adaptation
Monitoring the Western Australian preterm birth prevention initiative
description: Preterm birth, defined as delivery before 37 weeks' gestation, poses significant risks to neonatal health and can lead to long-term consequences. Cervical shortening is a common precursor to preterm birth, and prevents the mechanical reinforcement of the cervix, in maintaining the pregnancy. Topical vaginal progesterone and cervical cerclage are medical interventions aimed at prolonging gestation and reducing preterm birth rates. While cerclage is more effective in extreme cases of shortening (<10mm), combining progesterone with cerclage shows promise in moderately shortened cervixes (25-10mm). This prospective pilot study seeks to assess the efficacy of this combined approach in increasing gestational age and minimising neonatal complications.

name: What effect does virtual reality simulation have on final-year nursing students’ competence and confidence in performing non-technical skills?
description: The PhD by publication will entail a three-phase approach to explore the research question by engaging with the clinical experts in the nursing field, measuring Non-technical skills (NTS) performance and confidence across two different simulation modalities (in situ/face to face and virtual reality) and to provide an intervention to ascertain if virtual reality (VR) specific NTS training can enhance NTS performance and confidence in final-year nursing students.

name: The Aboriginal Land Inquiry: Recovering the Voices of the WA Land Rights Movement, 1983-1984
description:
This Honours project in History will investigate publicly available archival records held at the WA State Records Office about the 1983-1984 Western Australia Aboriginal Land Inquiry. In 1983, the Burke government commissioned the inquiry in an attempt to fulfill their election promise on land rights, appointing Justice Paul Seaman to find the best form of land rights for Western Australia. The inquiry emerged at a time of growing unrest and land rights activism among Aboriginal people, particularly in WA with the steady encroach of mining in the north-west, and creation of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act of 1976/77, that was passed by the Liberal Federal Government. Several hundred submissions were received from many sectors of WA society and more broadly.  These included Aboriginal organisations, the resource industry, pastoralists and graziers, community groups, academics, and lawyers. 
To date, limited to no historical research has been conducted on this project. This project seeks to place this Aboriginal Land Inquiry in its full historical context, including the fact that land – who owns it, and who has access to it – is at the core of settler-colonialism. This inquiry was the first time Indigenous communities had been asked about their vision for the future. This project seeks to recover their forgotten voices.

name: The Clinical Outcomes Of Indwelling Tunneled Pleural Catheter Use For Malignant Pleural Effusion In Metropolitan Sydney Hospitals
description: The purpose of this research project is to assess the clinical outcomes of patients using intercostal chest drain as a management of malignant pleural effusion within St George Hospital and Sutherland Hospital. It is a retrospective study assessing the clinical outcomes of managing malignant pleural effusion wit intercostal chest drain at St George Hospital and Sutherland Hospital, from 2019 to 2021.

name: A phenomenological exploration of midwives’ use and perception of gender-neutral language in maternity settings.
description: This proposed research is rooted in a feminist phenomenological approach, offering a nuanced understanding of midwives' experiences with gender-neutral language. By prioritising midwives' voices and narratives via semi structured interviews, it proposes to uncover the hidden power dynamics and normative influences. This proposed study aligns with feminist principles and the pursuit of true gender equality, shedding light on the complexities surrounding gender-neutral language. This research offers a unique opportunity to understand midwives' perspectives on using gender-neutral language, inform policies and provide guidance to promote inclusivity. Using a phenomenological approach with semi-structured interviews aims to foster a more participatory and respectful engagement with midwife participants, reinforcing trust and candid sharing of experiences.

name: The impact of 1:1 devices on student learning and engagement
description:
This research aims to examine the role of technology in teaching practice and the resulting impact of (technology-dominant) practice and 1:1 devices on student learning and engagement in SCS schools.

Objective
To investigate the advantages and challenges of using 1:1 devices compared to traditional notebook methods.
To gauge student engagement by measuring cognitive and affective engagement factors.

name: Evaluating the acceptability of an Acupuncture Program in an Inpatient Antenatal Hospital Unit: A Pilot Study
description:
There is a growing global demand to approach maternal healthcare in a more woman-centred, culturally sensitive, and humanised way (16). A national survey from Australia indicates that around half of all women giving birth experience some level of birth trauma within the maternity system, and that 85% of women would make different choices for their next birth (17). A humanised approach to maternal health care not only addresses the physical needs of mothers but also prioritises their mental, emotional, and social well-being. The evidence demonstrates that such approaches lead to better health outcomes, higher satisfaction, and reduced disparities, making it a beneficial model for maternal health care (18,19, 20, 21). Acupuncture supports humanised holistic care by providing personalised, integrative, and culturally sensitive treatments that address the mind-body connection, and thus, can play a supportive role in maternity care (22). Acupuncture’s ability to reduce stress, improve mental health (23,24, 25) and manage pain (26, 27) aligns well with the principles of holistic and humanised care and highlights acupuncture's role in enhancing patient-centred, comprehensive health care (28). 
Acupuncture services are not new to BC Women's Hospital, as acupuncture has been offered at the ‘Families In Recovery’ (FIR) Unit for 2.5 years, and is the most requested and utilised allied health service on the unit. Verbal feedback from the FIR unit's patients suggest that acupuncture significantly improved conditions such as mental health, sleep quality, stress levels, and other concerns. However, no formal evaluation of the service offered at FIR has occurred. Because of the noted success in the FIR unit, a pilot
program to expand to the antenatal unit (Evergreen) and the Reproductive Mental Health outpatient unit was created. This study, which evaluates this service, will be conducted at BC Women's antenatal unit, Evergreen, to examine what conditions acupuncture is most commonly requested for, and to examine its benefits or harms. The findings will help determine whether acupuncture positively supports clinical practice and if the services should be continued or expanded.

name: Herpes zoster vaccination and new diagnoses of dementia: A quasi-randomized study in the Lumos healthcare database
description: This project examines whether herpes zoster (HZ) vaccination reduces the risk of new dementia diagnoses. Using Lumos data, we aim to replicate earlier findings from the PenCS dataset, comparing outcomes in those aged 70–79 (eligible for vaccination in 2016) with those aged 80 and over (not eligible). With no cure for dementia and rising case numbers, identifying modifiable risk factors is critical. This analysis offers quasi-experimental evidence that may inform immunisation policy and support broader efforts to reduce the burden of dementia through prevention.

name: A retrospective analysis of leisure and lifestyle data across rural and metropolitan Mission Australia Aged Care Services
description: The average age of residents within Australian aged care facilities is 86 years old, comprising of 50% men and 50% women. This research project is focused on the aged care residents of the three Mission Australia aged care facilities, of which service a unique population. The people Mission Australia supports experience significant disadvantages such as physical or mental health concerns, and do not have a safe place to call home. As such, the age range in these sites is much younger, from 50-90 years old, and the gender breakdown is more male dominated, with 75% males and 25% females. Therefore, standardized aged care leisure and lifestyle applications may not be as relevant to these sites and this survey, which the government requires to be undertaken, will allow tailored consumer-centred care. The aim of our project is to analyse and compare the offerings leisure and lifestyle of rural and metropolitan Mission Australia Aged Care facilities and to facilitate more meaningful activities. The study objective is to ensure the leisure and lifestyle services provided to consumers at Mission Australia Aged Care sites are appropriate and relatable to them, as well as find aspects that need improvement.

name: Understanding and improving psychological, social and physical quality-of-life outcomes for paediatric burn patients an
description:
Quality of life is dependent on psychological and physical wellbeing. Paediatric burn patients have an increased long-term risk of a variety of serious health conditions such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, infectious disease, mental health conditions and cancer (1-6). Chronic inflammation and sustained changes to the immune system after a burn may be related to the increase in morbidities seen in this population regardless of burn size and scar outcome (7, 8).
Psychologically, poor mental health outcomes are more likely in a child who has been hospitalised for a burn injury compared to a peer who has not had a burn, and this remains true regardless of burn size, severity, and scar outcome. Psychosocial screening of patients and parents postburn might help us to understand baseline indicators of poor longer-term mental health recovery.
Physically, adults who have had a burn injury participate less in leisure-related physical activity (9), and have lower physical fitness (10). Paediatric burn patients might also have lower physical activity levels and impaired fitness resulting from physical and physiological limitations imposed by the burn, psychological limitations of the patient, overprotectiveness of the parent, or due to comorbidities secondary to burn.

name: UNDA Rural Clinical School & SJOG Ballarat Pharmacy -Chemotherapy & Compound Medications Sustainability in Quality Improvement Project
description: Description text

name: The role of belonging to a transnational faith community for international students at an Australian Catholic university
description: The project investigates the perceptions of international Catholic students during their transition into a Catholic university in Australia. No existing studies of this context have been found and the findings should inform and enrich understanding of and support for these students. Students will discuss their experiences in focus groups during their first semester and data will be transcribed and analysed qualitatively in order to identify themes. Findings will be disseminated through presentations and publications within and outside the university. This is NOT associated with a specific Faculty or School, so please ignore the fields below, which were compulsory, but did not include Student Experience as a unit involved in research.

name: Holistic Healthcare Needs of Women with Gestational Diabetes Living Across Metropolitan and Regional Australia
description: This descriptive study will examine an existing data set from a national survey of women who enrolled in the Australian National Diabetes Services Scheme and completed the ‘GDM Holistic Healthcare Needs Scale’.  This study seeks to further examine existing data from the scale evaluation which was conducted by the University of Canberra in collaboration with Diabetes Australia. This study will examine the same dataset to evaluate differences in the care needs of women living with GDM across different levels of geographical remoteness. This project seeks to develop a greater understanding of the holistic healthcare needs of women with GDM, including the impact of geographical remoteness and locality size, in order to improve GDM models of care across Australia. Comparative descriptive analysis of the dataset will use a non-parametric statistical test to compare the results of women based on their recorded postcode and corresponding class of remoteness according to the Modified Monash Model (MMM) for remoteness.

name: In people presenting to FSH and RGH Emergency Departments with musculoskeletal conditions, what are the effects of implementing physiotherapist led musculoskeletal diversion strategies on healthcare utilisation, patient outcomes and clinician satisfaction.
description: Investigation of the implementation of an emergency department diversion pathway at Fiona Stanley and Rockingham Hospitals

name: Breathlessness Rapid Evaluation And THErapy (BREATHE) - Process Evaluation
description: The primary objective of BREATHE SMART is to implement a system of patient self-screening in general practice “waiting rooms” that is fully integrated within practice IT systems and workflow. The self-screening system will link with electronic decision support that facilitates evidence-based management of dyspnoea in rural communities.

name: Exploring Buddhist Emptiness in Substance Addiction Recovery
description: The study aims to investigate how the Buddhist concept of emptiness relates to experiences of substance addiction recovery for people with long-term sobriety. The research will ask the question: "What is the significance of the Buddhist concept of emptiness to individuals in long-term recovery from substance addiction?" The aim is to capture the relationship between Buddhist emptiness and substance addiction recovery.

name: Validating and evaluating a multi-joint and isolated calf muscle testing battery
description: The research question associated with this project is “Can reliability and validity be established for testing protocols of the calf muscle that aim to closely replicate the functional demands placed on the calf muscle complex during running and field-based sports? The aims of this project are: 1. To develop a testing battery that assesses MVIC force outputs of the calf in both a vertical and horizontal plane, in a multi-joint position that replicates running demands. a. To assess ground reaction forces in the horizontal and vertical planes during a common calf rehabilitative exercise. 2. To establish the reliability of an isometric and dynamic assessment of calf muscle function. 3. To establish the validity of an isometric and dynamic assessment of calf muscle function. The insights from the MVIC testing battery and rehabilitative exercise performance have the potential to detect athletes at risk of CMSI and to improve rehabilitative practices following CMSI.

name: Is CT brain necessary in elderly patients on anticoagulant/antiplatelet therapy after minor head trauma with no other indications for intracranial haemorrhage?
description:
The aim of this study is to estimate the incidence of ICH and neurosurgical intervention for patients ≥75 years taking anticoagulant/antiplatelet agents who have had a suspected minor head injury but did not have any other indications for needing a scan on presentation. 

It is hypothesised that the incidence of ICH in elderly patients on anti-coagulant/antiplatelet therapy with no other indicators of head trauma (suspected open or depressed skull fracture; suspected base of skull fracture; vomiting ≥2 episodes; high risk mechanism, amnesia before impact >30 minutes; altered mental state or GCS; loss of consciousness; or alternative concern documented by clinician) will be similar to the emergency department incidence of ICH, which previous studies have estimated at 5%. Furthermore, from those with an ICH on brain CT scan, it is hypothesised that the vast majority will not have a neurosurgical/other intervention that varies from the conservative management for ICH.

name: Investigation and evaluation of teacher faith formation programs in Melbourne Archdiocesan Catholic Schools (MACS)
Development of two artefacts to support midwives to attain work-life balance: A Double Diamond study.
description:
The aim of this study is to develop two end-user co-designed and fit-for-context artefacts intended to support
midwives' work-life balance.

name: Hyperemesis Gravidarum and the Emergency Department: An evaluation of hospital-based treatment for nausea and vomiting in pregnancy and hyperemesis gravidarum.
description: The purpose of this project is to evaluate the management of women who present to an emergency department (ED) with nausea and vomiting in pregnancy (NVP) and/or hyperemesis gravidarum (HG) to develop recommendations for cost effective management and improved experience as both in- and out-patients. This project aims to quantify NVP and HG ED presentations, and determine the admission and management criteria for NVP and HG within the emergency setting. This will be achieved through a representative retrospective analysis of the Westmead Hospital ED database over a ten year period (2014-2024).

name: Nurse burn-out in the emergency department: What are the leading factors?
description:
Emergency departments (EDs) are crucial to the Australian health care system and the demand on them is increasing with nine million presentations to Australian public hospital ED’s in 2023-24. In addition, the wait times to see an ED physician or General Practitioner are increasing and this leads to extra pressure placed on emergency nurses, along with frustrated patients, which may lead to increased violence and aggression in the ED. 
Burn-out is becoming a worrying concern amongst ED nurses. The occupational stressors such as excessive workload, violence and aggression, and staff shortages are placing increased pressure on nurses, which is affecting nurses’ well-being and attrition. The increasing number of ED nurses leaving their job, and the nursing profession is concerning, therefore it is important to understand the stressors and employ strategies to protect these nurses from burn-out, which will may lead to improved retention and improved patient outcomes.

name: Maternity Acupressure Training for Healthcare Providers in India. Assessment Of Program Delivery at Fernandez Foundation and Associated Hospitals, Hyderabad India
description:
The use of acupressure and massage during childbirth has been shown to be effectiveness for supporting normal labour, reducing unnecessary medical interventions, and increasing satisfaction for women during birth. For hospitals, these approaches are low-cost and straight-forward to implement. Importantly acupressure and massage provide natural pain management and improve the experience of childbirth, which many women describe as traumatic due to medical interventions. 
To understand the effectiveness of the training program and to understand how these modalities are used maternity services, this study will use on online survey tool, containing 10-point scales to ask healthcare providers about any changes in their level of skill and knowledge in using these techniques before and after training, and then 6 months after training. 
We will also ask if they are using the skills 6 months after training, and what might help them to implement the skills more effectively.

name: Lived experience of diverse sexual identity in 1st generation Australians
description: This study will be an exploration into the lived experience of diverse sexual identity in first generation Australians. Through the utilisation of semi-structured interviews, this study aims to foster greater understanding of the experience of sexually diverse migrants and shed light on the unique struggles experienced by this group.

name: Longtermism and afterlife beliefs on moral concern for future generations
description: This study aims to investigate the relationships between longtermism beliefs and various beliefs about the afterlife (including religious perspectives) and the level of moral expansiveness toward future generations associated with each position. It involves a large scale quantitative online survey.

name: Clinician perspectives on caring for patients undergoing short conscious gynaecological procedures.
description:
Short, conscious gynaecological procedures are performed regularly at Women and Newborn Health Services (WNHS) as an essential component of caring for women.  This service contributes significantly to “A life course approach to health” as defined by the National Women’s Health Strategy 2020-2030 (2019), by way of preventative health, diagnosis, treatment and management of gynaecological conditions.  Anecdotal evidence from staff at King Edwards Memorial Hospital (KEMH) caring for patients undergoing these procedures, suggests there is a variation amongst patients’ experience of this service. 
Aim
This project aims to understand clinician’s perspectives and describe their experience regarding the provision of care for patients undergoing short, conscious gynaecological procedures to optimise care provision and identify areas for improvement. 
Methodology
Utilising a lens of quality improvement as defined by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC et al., 2023), this project will adopt a qualitative descriptive design to capture the perspectives of health professionals. 
Significance
Understanding the perspective of fellow clinicians on what their colleagues feel is done well and areas for improvement will provide evidence to assist in improving this model of service delivery.

name: Investigating the impact of acute surgery timing on short-term post-burn outcomes in adult burn patients
description:
Burns are one of the most common forms of traumatic injuries globally, and are
attributed to longer stays in hospital, particularly in the intensive care unit (ICU), compared to
other injuries. Burn pathophysiology is complex, consisting of multiple phases of disordered
metabolism that contribute to the challenge of burn treatment and management.
While there are studies in the published literature that provide evidence for the benefits
of early excision and grafting of burn wounds, there is still no consensus for the optimal timing
to burn surgery for adult patients, in terms of what is early and how to translate earlier surgery
into practise.
Using data collected in the Western Australian Burn Clinical Data Registry since 2004,
this retrospective cohort study aims to explore this gap in the literature. From a sample
population consisting of patients that underwent surgery for their burn injuries, patients will be
categorised into cohorts (<48 hours, 48 hours to 5 days, and >5 days) derived from the time
between burn diagnosis and burn surgery. The associations between time to surgery and
variables including length of hospital stay (LOS), duration of care, hospital-acquired
complications (HACs) and in-hospital intervention will be statistically analysed for
significance.
The results of this study aim to better inform surgical management of burns in an acute
setting. By potentially providing evidence for improved outcomes, these results will clarify the
optimal timing of burn surgery for better short-term post-operative outcomes.

name: ACL Injury Research Project
description: Retrospective analysis of acute anterior cruciate ligament injuries. Predictors of referral for surgical versus conservative management.

name: Assessing the Preparedness of Australian Nurses for Primary Care: An Evaluation of Primary Care Nursing Skill Sets
description: This project focuses on primary care nurses, whose role is crucial in ensuring access to healthcare, improving patient outcomes, reducing healthcare costs, supporting public health initiatives, and achieving health policy goals. Specifically, it aims to evaluate the preparedness of the Australian nursing workforce to address these opportunities. It aims to test the hypothesis that " the existing nursing education programs in Australia are not sufficient to equip graduates for effective job readiness in the primary care environment." This will be done by an analysis of  training nursing curricula and then a comparison made  between skills taught and those required to work in General Practice  and Primary Care nursing.

name: Measuring Patient-Centred Care: Common data sets for acupuncture trials across women’s lifespan
description:
This study is proposing a method for establishing a common outcome sets (COS) for acupuncture trials for women’s health across the lifespan. Using the methods described by the COMET Initiative (https://www.comet-initiative.org/), where common outcome measures are established in various health conditions, following a set process. 
This study aims to present a method for establishing common outcome sets (COS) for acupuncture for women’s health across the lifespan. We will describe a method for consultation and consensus using the process described by the COMET Initiative, where researchers, clinicians and consumers contribute to the creation a set of relevant outcome measures, meaningful to researchers, practitioners, and consumers for trials of interventions, which in this case is acupuncture trials in women’s health.

name: Evaluation of volunteer biography services in palliative care
description: This is a mixed-method cross-sectional evaluation study of volunteer biography services in two palliative care services, incorporating six stakeholder groups, palliative care patients, their family carers, bereaved carers, referrers, volunteer biographers and volunteer managers, all of whom will be asked to complete a questionnaire and participate in an interview.

name: Identifying unique immune mechanisms in melanoma patients with brain recurrence or pre-surgical progression on neoadjuvant therapy
description: This research project is designed to uncover the immunological drivers of treatment resistance in melanoma patients, specifically those who recur in the brain or exhibit disease progression before surgery while on neoadjuvant therapy. By identifying unique immune populations and markers of resistance, this project aims to better understand the underlying mechanisms that contribute to immunotherapy resistance and super progression in these patients. The insights gained could lead to the development or targeted therapeutic strategies the circumvent resistance and that can be further tested in mechanistic or pre-clinical models, ultimately improving patient outcomes and survival rates in these particularly challenging cases.

name: Prediction error in the testing effect; influences on learning and decision-making
description: This project examines whether intentionally introducing uncertainty into a well‐established causal learning paradigm (the allergist task) can enhance the testing effect. By manipulating the feedback to include uncertainty cues, we aim to measure improvements in retrieval practice and assess whether enhanced prediction errors lead to better retention and transfer of learned cause–effect associations. The outcomes may inform new teaching strategies to improve learning in classroom settings.

name: The role of stakeholder beliefs on the pedagogical decisions teachers make about play in early childhood
description: The primary purpose of this study is to investigate the beliefs and perspectives about play held by teachers, children and parents from a variety of schools and then consider how those beliefs and perspectives influence pedagogical decisions, and the provisions made for play in Western Australian (WA) Pre-Primary (PP) - Year 1 (Yr1) school settings. The aim of this study will be fourfold. First, to explore the beliefs, perspectives and practices of early childhood (EC) teachers who identify as being play-based in their approach to teaching and learning and consider how these beliefs are reflected in the environment, early childhood curriculum, teaching pedagogies and learning experiences employed in PP-Yr1. Second, to investigate the beliefs and practices of children towards play and play-based teaching and learning. Third, to explore the beliefs and perspectives of parents towards play and play-based teaching and learning. Finally, the research will aim to provide an in-depth account of the actual affordances and hindrances to play and implementing a play-based approach during these critical EC years in WA.

name: A Prospective Cohort Study Evaluating the use of Ritual, Spiritual Orientation and Coping
description: Our primary objective is to better understand the range, type and frequency of rituals commonly practiced by patients with an advanced illness and an estimated prognosis of ≤12 months.  Secondarily, this study seeks to better understand what spiritual practices patients would like to have in their lives but currently do not.  Thirdly, we seek correlations between patient/carer coping, quality of life and subjective spirituality and practices of rituals that are personally or culturally meaningful activities.

name: The THRIVE study- Transformative Healing Resources In Valuable Environments, identifying intrinsic and extrinsic factors that support Post Traumatic Growth in Nurses
description:
This mixed-method explanatory sequential research will recruit registered nurses via social media sites to identify intrinsic and extrinsic factors that promote post traumatic growth. The aim is to identify intrinsic and extrinsic factors that support nurses following crisis. 
 A validated instrument the Post Traumatic Growth Inventory, will be used in the quantitative phase to measure Personal Strength, Spiritual Change, New Possibilities, Appreciation of Life and Relation to others. The qualitative phase will comprise focus groups from the sub-disciplines of nurses: academics; clinicians; researchers; and managers and will explore intrinsic and extrinsic factors related to growth. Descriptive statistics will be used to analyse quantitative data and thematic analysis will be used for qualitative data. The team comprises nurses from academia, research, clinical and management. 
Prof Betihavas who is the CI on this project has experience researching post traumatic growth as an investigator within national and international research teams.

name: A qualitative case study of paediatric war injuries in Gaza – the healthcare provider perspective.
description: This descriptive qualitative study aims to document the nature and consequences of the problems precipitated by serious limb injuries and amputations in children in Gaza from the perspective of health professionals involved in their care.

name: Assessing the Role of Churches and Christian Values in Bridging Gender Equality Gaps in the Solomon Islands
description: This research aims to assess whether the Christian church and its values serve as an effective tool for changing attitudes and behaviours related to gender inequality in the Solomon Islands.
