The study will explore how participants perceive gender inequality within their communities and how these views are shaped by Christian beliefs, by collecting primary qualitative data through interviewing participants from five major church denominations in the Solomon Islands. It will also include interviews with key informants such as church leaders, NGO representatives, and program implementers to understand their roles in addressing gender inequality and their views on the effectiveness of faith-based initiatives in shifting harmful gender norms.

name: The Archaeology of Point Possession
description: The project aims to answer questions regarding the meaning of many archaeological sites that are located mostly on exposed granite outcrops near Point Possession (part of the Vancouver Peninsula). Using pedestrian transects, one will identify and record the location of the area’s archaeology, producing maps that will allow the Aboriginal community to monitor and care for the archaeology in the future.

name: SToP (See, Treat, Prevent) skin sores and scabies trial: study protocol for a cluster randomised, stepped-wedge trial for skin disease control in remote Western Australia
description: The SToP trial is an (open-cohort) stepped-wedge cluster randomised trial that aims to evaluate a skin health programme comprising three intervention components (1) seeing skin infections; (2) treating skin infections; and (3) preventing skin infections. Four community clusters in the remote Kimberley region of Western Australia participated in the study. The primary outcome is the diagnosis of impetigo in children (5–9 years) observed during school-based surveillance visits.

name: Connections to people, places and God, 2 years on from an immersive experience in the Holy Land
description: The purpose of this research is to use student data from post-graduate students at the University of Notre Dame, Fremantle campus enrolled in Master courses in Religious Education, from one-on-one semi-structured interviews to assess the on-going effects of a pilgrimage to Israel, after two years of the pilgrimage.  An additional aim is ascertaining the extent that the pilgrimage experience has impacted on the students who are teachers and leaders of Religious Education (RE) in Catholic schools.

name: Trends in Intracerebral Haemorrhage (ICH) hospitalisations and surgical management in Western Australia from 2000 - 2022: data-linkage study.
description: Intracerebral haemorrhage (ICH) is the subtype of stroke with the most devastating consequences. Despite advances in the medical and surgical management of ICH, the one-month mortality rate is 35%. Trends in ICH have not been studied before in Western Australia. Therefore this study will use a linked dataset of WA hospitalisation and death records to assess trends in ICH hospitalisations. The study will also look at which surgical procedures are being performed and assess these trends. This project is a subset of an existing project titled 'The Real and Changing Atherothrombotic Disease Burden and Secondary Prevention'.

name: The lived experience of young adults’ use of online and offline spaces in gender identity development
description: The aim of this project is to investigate the experiences and preferences of gender diverse young adults during gender identity exploration across online and offline spaces (i.e., settings, locations, social media platforms, etc).

name: The lived experience of providing services in rural areas under the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS)
description: This project will be used to explore the experience of rural-based clinicians and support workers who provide services to people accessing the National Disability Insurance Scheme. Study participants will be accessed through contact details sourced from the publicly available database of NDIS service providers. Recruitment will also be sought through snowball sampling by asking participants if there are other key informants that may be able to provide insight into this phenomena. Participants will be asked to engage in a semi structured interview and provide demographic data. This next phase of the project will explore the experiences and perceptions of rural-based medical practitioners, specifically general practitioners and paediatricians who are involved in supporting people who have a disability, reside in a rural area of Australia and receive funding under the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS). We will conduct semi-structured interviews by phone, video call or face-to-face about their experiences supporting people receiving NDIS funding/ Interviews will be transcribed and thematically analysed.

name: Mortality of people with lived experience of homelessness in Western Australia based on coronial data
description: The aim of this project is to develop comprehensive mortality profiles and investigate the role of housing status in deaths amongst people with lived experience of homelessness in Western Australia. The project objectives are to (i) develop comprehensive mortality profiles of PEH in WA based on coronial data, including with respect to age, cause of death, and amenability to early intervention or treatment, (ii) investigate the extent to which known medical treatments (e.g., cancer treatments) were being utilised by individuals in our cohort around the time of their deaths, (iii) investigate and characterise the extent to which past and present living situation/housing status is documented in Australian coronial data and (iv) investigate the extent to which the living situation/housing status of PEH in our cohort prior to and at the time of their deaths played a role in those deaths.

name: Quantifying ischemic preconditioning "dose" using thiol oxidation state of albumin
description: This project aims to investigate the response of a novel blood marker to an ischemic preconditioning protocol that can be used to enhance performance in elite athletes. Ischemic preconditioning involves the use of cycles of blood flow restriction prior to exercise in order to stimulate a protective mechanism in the body which leads to enhanced exercise performance. The outcomes of this investigation will show whether it is possible to detect changes in albumin, which is the most abundant protein in human blood, as a result of the IPC protocol and subsequent exercise.

name: Strategic leadership and educational change: Exploring the importance of planning and leading for success in schools
description: The project will investigate the role of Strategic Leadership in achieving change within schools. Through using case study methodology, the investigation will use semi-structured interviews, a survey and document analysis to build a conceptual model of Strategic Leadership and how it creates conditions for change.

name: Spiritual wellbeing: the perceptions of Catholic school principals in Western Australia
description:
The aim of the research project is to explore the perceptions of Catholic school principals about their spiritual wellbeing. In particular, to explore ways the principals consider their spiritual wellbeing is supported, and how their spiritual wellbeing influences their role and how they lead. 
Given this aim, there are two research questions:
1.	In what ways do Catholic school principals perceive their spiritual wellbeing is supported?
2.	How do Catholic school principals perceive their spiritual wellbeing influences their role and how they lead?

name: On-Country cross-cultural immersion programs for the Western Australian judiciary: A participatory action research project to inform design, delivery and impact
description: This Participatory Action Research (PAR) project seeks to determine what is ‘best practice’ in the design, delivery and evaluation of on-Country cross-cultural education programs for judges in WA, and to what extent these programs are leading to changes in policy and practice. Co-researchers will include people who are (or have been) involved in the on-Country immersions, including judicial representatives, on-Country hosts, facilitators and interpreters. An Aboriginal Reference Group will oversee the cultural aspects of the research. Methods include one-on-one interviews, courtroom observations, and analysis of court documents. The co-researchers in the PAR will use the findings to inform the design, delivery and evaluation of future programs; develop a 'Theory of change for two-way learning'; and create a framework to inform future evaluations of on-Country programs. The project ultimately aims to build towards a more culturally-safe court environment for Aboriginal people in Western Australia’s criminal justice system.

name: Researching the lived experience of First Nations Peoples on prepayment meters
description: Our project will build upon these previous research studies to better understand the lived experience of consumers using prepayment metering across Australia. Across the jurisdictions in which pre-payment operates there are likely to be diverse views and experiences about its impact on energy security, consumer rights and protections, and community wellbeing. This will be based on prevailing temperatures and whether solar has been rolled out in these communities. There are also differences in how prepayment for electricity operates in the Northern Territory, Western Australia, South Australia, and Queensland.

name: Exploring General Practitioners’ communication preferences from pharmacists in Asthma and COPD management: A qualitative focus group study
description: The aim of the study is to improve interprofessional collaboration between general practitioners (GPs) and community pharmacists (CPs) by exploring GPs’ communication preferences from pharmacists, which will support the development of efficient and timely communication pathways. This will lead to safer and more coordinated care for patients with asthma and COD, especially in relation to medications and supporting treatment adherence according to the previous studies. The objectives are (1) to explore GP’s preferences and expectations regarding communication from pharmacists in terms of asthma and COPD management, (2) to assess challenges and barriers that GPs encounter secondary to the current lack of a systematic communication strategy around GPs and pharmacists, (3) to identify enablers that support interprofessional collaboration from the insights of GPs, and (4) to identify recommendations for GPs-pharmacists communication strategies aligned with the existing GPs’ electronic medical record (eMR)and clinical workflows.

name: Comparison of stability of Saturne and Pinnacle uncemented acetabular cups
description: Retrospective study analysing patients of The Joint Studio (Hollywood Medical Center) who underwent total hip arthroplasty between 2018-2023. The clinical outcomes and patient satisfaction ratings of two brands of uncemented hip implants will be assessed: the Pinnacle (DePuy) and the Saturne (Amplitude) acetabular cups. This will enable conclusions to be drawn about the stability of each hip implant (likelihood of dislocation).

name: Why we came and stayed: understanding a lifetime of occupational experiences of senior rural nurses to impact the future: A Mixed Method Study
description: The aim of this research project is to explore how the experiences of senior rural nurses and the perspectives of the newly graduated nurses can be used to impact the future attraction and retention of rural nurses

name: Jumping In: The Impact the Olympics has on Sports and Participation rates in Swimming Clubs and Little Athletics and the Impact this has on Participation Rates in independent schools Across Western Australia.
description: This study aims to explore the impact the Olympic games has on participation rates in sporting clubs and the impact that this four year cycle has on participation rates in schools across Western Australia. The data was collected from, Swimming Western Australia, Athletics West and Independent school in Western Australia. In this study there is a trend analysing the increase of participation rates in sporting clubs after the Olympics every four years from 2015 to  2024. The data is categorised yearly participation rates from Swimming Western Australia (WA), Athletics West. As well as the impact the Olympics has on Independent schools participation in swimming and athletics. These results indicate that there is a four-year cycle impacting sporting clubs’ for both swimming and athletics participation. Likewise there is a  correlation impacting positively on Independent schools. This study also serves as a guide to make recommendations that schools consider adapting programs with the potential to see greater participation co-synced with the four year Olympics cycle.

name: Healthcare Interprofessional Education (IPE) online experience
description: Collaborative student activities delivered online around a fictional patient scenario to advance Interprofessional learning (IPE) and cooperation. The IPE was previously delivered f2f but the team created an online environment and now seeks to evaluate the students' use of and collaboration within the range of activities. We also wish to understand if there were a change in the students' confidence levels.

name: Impact of NICU admission on term infants’ feeding choices at Fiona Stanley Hospital: Barriers, Facilitators and Outcomes
description: Retrospective cohort study investigating the rate of breastmilk at first feed and discharge in the Neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) for term neonates (>37 weeks gestation). The project investigates hospital data from Fiona Stanley for both mother and infant dyads, where term neonates born were admitted to the NICU.

name: A Cross-Sectional Study of Australian Shamanic Healers: Training Backgrounds, Healing Interventions, and Attitudes Toward Mental Health Professions
description: This study is a cross-sectional survey of Australian shamanic healers. It explores the training Australian shamanic healers have undertaken along with the interventions they use when providing shamanic healings to people for emotional and mental health problems. The study also explores their personal mental health experiences and their attitudes towards traditional mental health providers such as general practitioners and psychologists.

name: NESP MaC Project 1.33 - Application of environmental DNA to survey Bathurst Harbour Tasmania for the endangered Maugean skate (IMAS)
description:
The Maugean skate (*Zearaja maugeana*) is listed as Endangered under Tasmania’s *Threatened Species Protection Act and the Commonwealth Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999*. Its known population is small (~3,000 individuals, Macquarie Harbour, 2016) and highly restricted, having only been recorded in two isolated estuaries: Bathurst Harbour and Macquarie Harbour in south-western/western Tasmania. This constitutes one of the most limited distributions of any known extant elasmobranch.

Although the skate was first discovered in Bathurst Harbour, most knowledge of the species stems from the Macquarie Harbour population. Only four individuals have been reported in Bathurst Harbour, with the last reported sighting in 1992. Environmental conditions in Macquarie Harbour have changed markedly since then due to anthropogenic activities in and around the estuary including historical mining, hydro-electric generation and alteration of natural river flows, and marine fish farming.

Previous research has shown clear signs of population stress and evidence of detrimental impacts of degraded environmental conditions on the Maugean Skate in Macquarie Harbour. Understanding the potential population status of the Maugean Skate in Bathurst Harbour will assist in determining conservation actions. This study used Environmental (e) DNA to determine the presence/absence of the endangered Maugean skate (Zearaja maugeana) in Bathurst Harbour, strengthening the evidence base for effective conservation plans and specific recovery actions.

name: West Kimberley Climate Adaptation
description: The project will engage West Kimberley Traditional Owners and the State Government to build a body of evidence combining Indigenous Science and Western science to develop an Indigenous-led West Kimberley climate change adaptation and resilience strategy.

name: West Kimberley Climate Adaptation
description: The project will engage West Kimberley Traditional Owners and the State Government to build a body of evidence combining Indigenous Science and Western science to develop an Indigenous-led West Kimberley climate change adaptation and resilience strategy.
